before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"modq","text":"Before starting, prepare stock solutions/reagents as described in steps 1-4 of the protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"co0s9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21fuj","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"369lv","text":"This protocol accompanies Expansion Sequencing (ExSeq), and describes the process of performing in situ sequencing with the Illumina chemistry.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":26,"length":28}],"data":{}},{"key":"ap6ea","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8qgb","text":"The steps here are an extension of the protocol used in the original paper and are optimized for reading longer barcodes of up to seven bases. For shorter barcodes (less than four bases) in brain tissue, we recommend using the experimental protocol from the paper (with the imaging conditions as described in this protocol) as it is simpler and slightly faster.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4q1e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2tsmm","text":"There are two stages to this protocol: (1) sample preparation (steps 5-10), involving anchoring the sample to a glass-bottom plate and preparing the sample for sequencing; and (2) in situ sequencing using the Illumina sequencing-by-synthesis chemistry (steps 11-15). After in situ sequencing is complete, there is an optional antibody staining recovery step (step 16) if antibody staining was performed during tissue preparation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":180,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":273,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkep6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32l4i","text":"The relationship between template bases and fluorophores is shown in Fig. 1A. Note that the added base (that bears the fluorophore) is the complementary base, i.e. the modified dCTP from the Illumina reagents bears the most redshifted dye. The specific length 7, Hamming distance 3 logical barcode library used in these protocols is shown in Fig. 1B, with the specific readout strategy for Illumina in situ sequencing shown in Fig. 1C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":69,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":342,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":427,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":399,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"99ruo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4tivp","text":"The process of Illumina sequencing-by-synthesis in situ is shown in Fig. 1D. There are three key steps: an incorporation step, in which the next base of the barcode is synthesized; an imaging step, in which the sample is imaged on a spinning disk confocal microscope; and a cleavage step, in which the dye is cleaved, and the reversible terminator is unblocked, enabling the next round of synthesis to be performed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":48,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":68,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d137","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a071m","text":"This protocol was used to profile human metastatic breast cancer biopsies as a part of the Human Tumor Atlas Pilot Project.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"6A0286F0D90011EBB835ABA829C9C241","height":434,"id":188864,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"Targeted_ExSeq_ISS_Overview.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2qc9yv6.jpg","shadow":false,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2qa9yv6.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2qb9yv6.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/f2p99yv6.webp","width":550}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"64B9A3E0D64411EBB32AB93E9FD4A742","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33509999/"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2rtc1","text":"Preparation of Sample","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74vdg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"288dp","text":"This protocol assumes that samples have been prepared following the Targeted ExSeq Tissue Preparation protocol, and that a sequencing library has been prepared following the Targeted ExSeq Library Preparation protocol. The padlock probes to generate the library should have been prepared following the Targeted ExSeq Probe Generation protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ault9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9osq","text":"The protocol assumes that the library has been prepared, and if the amplicons were optionally checked, that the detection oligos have been stripped off as described in the Library Preparation protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"67eml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c4f6a","text":"Overview of Second Re-embedding","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tki6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4kk2v","text":"To minimize any movement during the multiple rounds of imaging during in situ sequencing, the sample gel is immobilized to a glass-bottom plate for all subsequent steps. This is accomplished by functionalizing wells of a glass-bottom plate with acryloyl groups (Step 6), and casting a second re-embedding gel to anchor the gel to the plate (Step 7).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":70,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4v0u0","text":"Overview of Sequencing Preparation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aqd7n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75k7","text":"In this step, we prepare the glass-anchored sample for in situ sequencing with the Illumina chemistry. There are two primary steps here: (1) capping terminal 3' DNA ends of cellular DNA with dideoxy nucleotides; and (2) hybridization of the Illumina sequencing primer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":55,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9r6cr","text":"Dideoxy Capping of 3' DNA Strands","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"802jr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8lc75","text":"To minimize background from base addition to exposed 3' ends of cellular DNA during the Illumina incorporation, Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is used to add dideoxynucleotides to block further extension.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"679si","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"f9n14","text":"Casting Second Re-embedding Gel","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1trsb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb6lp","text":"This gelling step is similar to the first re-embedding step from the tissue preparation protocol, but does not have an extended pre-incubation step.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"co8ru","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f0ume","text":"The purpose of the second re-embedding gel is to anchor the sample gel to the glass by incorporating the acryloyl groups on the glass surface into the second re-embedding polyacrylamide gel, which penetrates into the sample gel. {"blocks":[{"key":"12r1c","text":"Overview of Imaging","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j02l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f6au5","text":"The specifics of imaging vary significantly from microscope to microscope. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3l4qp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c7kng","text":"In general, users will be performing tiled array imaging, where each tile is a multicolor Z-section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f5t50","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4pkdb","text":"We recommend a 2% overlap between tiles to minimize photobleaching of amplicons at the edges of tiles. We recommend a spacing of 0.4 μm between adjacent Z-sections, and we recommend setting up the image acquisition to image all Z-places for a color channel before moving on to the next color channels. Imaging should be performed from longest to shortest excitation wavelength. Take care when setting up the image acquisition to ensure that the sample will be fully covered in Z across the entire XY region, since a small sample tilt can result in a significant fraction of the sample being out of the imaged volume.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o586","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21kdh","text":"This protocol is optimized for imaging on a Dragonfly spinning disk confocal microscope, using a Nikon 40X water immersion, long working distance, NA 1.15 objective (MRD77410).
